Cameroon - Western Highlands Rural
            Development Project

subtopic: Regional Rural Development,Crops and Crop Management Systems,Economic Theory & Research,Agricultural Knowledge and Information Systems,Agricultural Research

0.cdata!:
Cameroun - Projet de Developpement Rural
            des Hauts Plateaux de l'Ouest

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Western Highlands
            Rural Development Project for Cameroon was to intensify the
            cultivation of all crops included in the prevailing farming
            system while introducing measures to prevent the erosion and
            loss of soil fertility due to the over population of the
            area. To reach its objective, the project was to: (a)
            strengthen the planning unit in the Ministry of Agriculture
            and strengthen and equip a new directorate of production
            services in Union des Cooperatives de Cafe Arabica de
            l'Ouest (UCCAO); (b) establish a seed farm and
            construct 10 new rural service centers and 220 village water
            points; (c) develop about 400 ha of bottomland; (d)
            introduce better processing equipment; and (e) establish a
            training center, a monitoring and evaluation unit, and a
            revolving credit fund. Lessons learned include: (a) the
            difficulty of addressing a key national policy issue in the
            context of a regional project. Low coffee producer prices
            (relatively and as a share of export price) made coffee
            relatively unattractive; (b) insufficient attention was paid
            to linking and conveying the applied research unit findings
            (field trials and demonstrations) to the extension service.
            This resulted in the latter not having enough messages to
            convey to farmers, and extension did not effectively convey
            farmers-priorities and problems to research; and (c) given
            the complexity of the technical issues in this type of
            project, regular visits by an agronomist are essential.
